1481015730543992835.text: @HouseDems These bills would work in tandem, with the Freedom to Vote Act responding to current threats to our democracy, and the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act preventing states from enacting discriminatory voting laws going forward. I urge the Senate to pass both bills.

1481015637828845573.text: This bill, which @HouseDems passed, would prevent states from enacting laws which are designed to make it harder to vote for people of color. It is time for the Senate to advance H.R. 4 to restore protections for the right to vote.

1481015530664468480.text: The John R. Lewis Voting Advancement Rights Act restores the requirement that states with a history of racial discrimination in voting receive approval from the DOJ in order to make changes to voting systems.

1481015420148723731.text: The Freedom to Vote Act includes similar provisions to H.R. 1, the For the People Act, which I cosponsored and voted for when it passed the House in March 2021. Unfortunately, this important voting rights legislation has stalled in the Senate.

1481015323960688650.text:
The Freedom to Vote Act, led by @SenAmyKlobuchar, sets nationwide standards to protect American’s vote. It would:
✅Expand automatic voter registration
✅Make Election Day a holiday
✅Strengthen vote-by-mail and early voting
✅Prevent election subversion 
✅& other reforms

1481014823357980673.text: The anniversary of Jan. 6 reminds us of the danger that our democracy faces and its vulnerability to election subversion. It is time to pass the Freedom to Vote Act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Act to protect our democracy and the sacred right to vote.

1479181285486739470.text: As a nation, we must have a full understanding of what happened on Jan. 6. 1479181231086620677.text: The experience of a violent attempt to overthrow democratic institutions brought back intense memories of my childhood in Cuba. It was a terrifying moment that I never imagined would happen in the country that took my family in when we fled a violent dictatorship.

1479181165948977156.text: A year ago today, our democracy was attacked by a violent mob inspired by the former President and his lies about the 2020 election. The former President has had an entire year to take responsibility for his actions, yet he has chosen to continue to lie to his supporters.

1395113155156758530.text: As I said in my remarks today, the U.S. Government is ready to work with El Salvador’s government to address the root causes of migration, but we will not compromise democratic values in doing so.

1395113006179180551.text: Attacks on judicial independence in El Salvador are our business. U.S. taxpayers have helped support anti-corruption investigations and programs to strengthen the rule of law in the country. My colleagues and I are committed to protecting those investments.

1395112782471876613.text: Today, @HouseForeign passed a bipartisan resolution I introduced with @RepMcCaul, @RepGregoryMeeks, & @RepMarkGreen, condemning the removal of 5 judges and the attorney general & urging the government of #ElSalvador to respect the separation of powers. 1382431215920295940.text: Hoy convoqué una audiencia sobre las causas fundamentales de migración desde Centroamérica. 1382424930399232000.text: I commend President Biden for his commitment to deepening the U.S. partnership with the people of Central America and I look forward to continuing to work closely with his administration to advance our shared goals.

1382424929577144323.text: U.S. assistance to Central America should be directed to local organizations working at the community level to address the push factors driving migration. We should engage civil society to ensure the promotion of human rights is at the core of our Central America strategy.

1382424928813731841.text: I emphasized that the U.S. must aggressively tackle corruption while helping expand economic opportunity in Central America. Let’s start by imposing sanctions against each of the corrupt officials in Guatemala’s Congress who captured the Constitutional Court today.

1349481210255446016.text: My staff and I would like to thank everyone who has reached out with concerns for our safety and wellbeing. January 6th was horrific on multiple levels as we watched barricades fall to an attack on our democracy and the place where we work for the 8th District of New Jersey.

1349479265956466693.text: For his actions, I have voted to impeach President Trump for a second time. He must be held accountable for the damage he has done to our nation.

1349479075463766016.text: He refused to disavow white supremacy and right-wing hate groups, instead telling them to stand by. Immediately before the traumatic events of January 6th, he actively incited violence, whipped up hatred, and directed a mob to the Capitol.

1349478583606108163.text: None of this had to happen. President Trump could have put the nation, and our democratic institutions, over his own pride and greed. He chose not to. Instead of accepting the possibility of losing a second term, he preemptively chipped away at faith in our electoral system.

1341460254308114433.text: 21/There are also key modifications to PPP to serve the smallest businesses and struggling non-profits and better assist independent restaurants…

1341460252663967744.text: 20/The agreement includes over $284 billion for first and second forgivable PPP loans, dedicates set-asides for very small businesses and lending through community-based lenders like CDFIs and MDIs.

1341460249870536704.text: 19/The bill continues support for small businesses with critical funding and policy changes to help small businesses, including minority, women and veteran owned small businesses.

1341460248041844736.text: 18/$300 per week in UI enhancement was included for Americans out of work and an 11-week extension for benefits was also included.

1341460246682886144.text: 17/Included is another round of direct payments worth up to $600 per adult or child, not nearly enough to help all those struggling but a step in the right direction of getting relief directly to those who need it.

1341460244443099138.text: 16/The funding will also implement a strong national testing and tracing strategy with billions reserved specifically for combating the disparities facing communities of color and to support our heroic health care workers and providers.

1341460124867694592.text: 15/The package acknowledges that COVID-19 needs to be brought under control before we can start to see long-term economic stability by accelerating free and equitable vaccine distribution.

1341460123324178433.text: 14/Fights for a more humane immigration approach, reducing funding for ICE’s overly aggressive detention and removal activities by $431 million below the fiscal year 2020 level.

1341460121562591236.text: 13/The bill includes funding to tackle food insecurity, with robust investments in WIC, child nutrition programs, and SNAP to help ensure children and families have the nutrition they need.

1341460119532544015.text: 12/It affirms our commitment to improving our environment with $9.24 billion, a $180 million increase, for the Environmental Protection Agency to ensure clean air and water and to hold polluters accountable.

1341460118416846848.text: 11/…and $12.9 billion for IDEA Special Education Grants to States, an increase of $173 million above the FY 2020 enacted level.

1341460116785258500.text: 10/The bill also supports better schools, with $16.5 billion for Education for the Disadvantaged Grants to Local Educational Agencies, an increase of $227 million above the FY 2020 enacted level…

1341460114860027904.text: 9/$82 billion in funding would be provided for colleges and schools, including support for HVAC repair and replacement to mitigate virus transmission and reopen classrooms.

1341460113752797185.text: 8/It expands access to housing, providing $43.4 million in new targeted vouchers to reduce homelessness among families with children, individuals, the unsheltered, veterans, and survivors of domestic violence.

1341460112234471425.text: 7/There is $25 billion in critically needed rental assistance for families struggling to stay in their homes and an extension of the eviction moratorium.

1341460109780762625.text: 6/I wanted to take some time to highlight provisions included in the COVID-19 relief section as well as programs that would be funded through the end of FY 2021:

1341460108547645440.text: 5/So last night I voted for the funding package as a step to ensuring our government won’t shut down while we build on the relief that was included.

1341460107318751233.text: 4/I believe that at this point, our main priority should be getting aid, any aid, to families, health care workers, patients, and all those who need our help.

1341460106073006080.text: 3/I’ve pushed for this plan and House Democrats have passed multiple large aid packages that were left to languish in the Senate as McConnell’s Republicans claimed that aid to struggling families was less important than the deficit.

1341460104156221442.text: 2/Since early March, I have been a strong supporter of @RepMaxineWaters  comprehensive, long term plan to fight the virus and its consequences. Her plan included monthly stimulus payments, eviction and foreclosure moratoriums, rental assistance, and more.

1341460102423977984.text: 1/Last night, the House passed a funding package that would provide funding through the remainder of fiscal year 2021, preventing a potential government shutdown as we continue to battle COVID-19. The package also included desperately needed pandemic relief.

1341401132753694724.text: Last night the House passed an appropriations package to fund the government through the rest of the fiscal year. Included in the package is a $900 billion COVID-19 relief bill that includes many provisions House Democrats and I fought to include for the American people.

1288861894460223490.text: Unfortunately, Senate Republicans have refused to vote on this legislation, leaving many Americans financially adrift with no prospect of relief in sight.

1288861893575286784.text: The Heroes Act would provide an additional $1,200 stimulus check to Americans, extend the $600 weekly federal unemployment benefit, provide billions in relief funds for renters, and $75 billion for COVID-19 testing, tracing, and mitigation.

1265312361273004033.text: Since I first came to Congress I have continually fought for necessary funding to update infrastructure like the Portal Bridge. I am glad to see these funds disbursed that will help secure the Portal Bridge while keeping our infrastructure and economy moving.

1265312360476160000.text: This funding will allow for appropriate changes that will ensure the full operation of the Portal Bridge.

1265312359515643905.text: This century-old bridge has desperately needed funding for years. Although a crucial piece of infrastructure for the Northeast, the bridge sometimes has to be locked into place by workers with sledgehammers.

1265312358597001218.text: The Portal Bridge is essential in connecting the entire northeast corridor from Boston to Washington D.C. The bridge carries an average of 450 trains and 200,000 passengers each day, and is essential for moving the economy of NJ and the entire Northeast.

1265312357028442119.text: The Federal Railroad Administration just announced $91.5 million in funding to help advance the replacement of the Portal North Bridge and to make upgrades along the Amtrak Northeast Corridor (NEC). https://t.co/u6QCEcTapM

1263564762518040577.text: @colinmahns Hi Colin, I believe that this bill could help in our long-term economic recovery from COVID-19 but I also agree that people need assistance now which is why I've been pushing for tangible aid like a $100 bil rental assistance program & recurring emergency payments.

1263559354722193415.text: I understand that people with bills to pay, and families to take care of want to get back to work. As we look to our future economic recovery, this legislation would create a local job engine that equips trainees with skills that fill employment gaps in local areas.

1263559116770992128.text: This sensible policy will provide long-term unemployed individuals with well paying, secure job opportunities while also helping our local businesses flourish.

1263559115021959168.text: Local businesses would also be eligible to receive up to $4,000 in tax credits for tuition costs for each job that is filled by someone who has been unemployed for 90+ days so they can obtain the required certificate or training credential.

1263558871483912197.text: Funding would go to programs that create long-term and income secure job opportunities for trainees.

1263558870091403265.text: These partnerships will equip workers with skills that match the unique needs of their communities.

1263558685516800002.text: H.R. 4848, would combine the strength of local businesses and community colleges by creating a $1 billion tax credit program to encourage partnerships between local businesses and community colleges.

1263558684011102213.text: I’ve been working with @SenatorMenendez on the Better Education and Skills Training (BEST) for America’s Workforce Act.

1263558329131053057.text: Getting long-term unemployed New Jerseyans back to work is one of my biggest priorities. Due to the effects of COVID-19 we will need more solutions to help our workforce get moving again.

1261670482291462144.text: I voted for this bill because we cannot stand idly by when we are presented with the opportunity to help those in need. Read my full statement here: https://t.co/BCuA2N5e8a

1261670451878780929.text: The Heroes Act seeks to address the challenges so many are struggling with by supporting programs for workers, the unemployed, renters, small businesses, health care systems, and more.

1261422366082523136.text: @MyLifeIsMunitz @RepTimRyan @RoKhanna @RepJayapal @RashidaTlaib Hey Jon, I've been pushing for recurring payments like the ones included in Chairwoman Waters' plan from March and last week I cosponsored H.R. 6496, the Emergency Money for the People Act https://t.co/lE00FolXpj

1261401930690998273.text: It would also authorize $5 bil for schools & libraries to provide internet services for students & teachers by providing laptops, wi-fi hotspots, & more, would provide student debt relief & puts in place a temporary suspension of payments for all federal student loan borrowers.

1261401729611862016.text: This funding is flexible and can be used to address the unique needs of different communities and can support purchasing technology, providing counseling and mental health services for students and staff, and authorized activities under IDEA and ESEA.

1261401673764921345.text: COVID-19 has driven home that our school systems are not equal and that not everyone has the ability to carry on their education remotely. The Heroes Act begins to address this disparity by providing $90 billion for a State Fiscal Stabilization Fund.

1261401580974325768.text: Last but certainly not least, here are some of the education provisions in the Heroes Act: https://t.co/ajMGXeo0u5

1261388911261233152.text: The Heroes Act would provide $500 billion directly to state governments and $375 billion for local governments so that we can protect those on the frontlines and ensure that the virus does not decimate public services.

1261388664187355136.text: New Jersey has been hit hard by COVID-19 and our local governments are in desperate need of assistance to pay vital workers such as health care workers, police, firefighters, transportation workers, EMS, and teachers.

1261388535904505857.text: It would strengthen the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) to ensure that underserved communities are not overlooked & improves PPP forgiveness by extending covered period. It would provide another $10 billion for EIDL grants including cash advances that don't need to be paid back

1261387671252824064.text: Our neighborhood mom and pop shops are the backbone of our communities and the economic toll of COVID-19 is putting many of them at risk. The Heroes Act would build upon the programs put in place in previous stimulus packages to help small businesses ride out the storm.

1261387551723618304.text: We are still debating the Heroes Act so let's review some provisions for small businesses, states, and municipalities: https://t.co/ajMGXeo0u5

1261371537778601984.text: $7 billion would be set aside for Child Care and Development Block Grants and another $850 million would go to the Social Services Block Grant to fund child and family care for essential workers.

1261371514714312704.text: Also included is emergency funding for school meal programs and the Child and Adult Care Food Program as well as support for services such as home-delivered meals.

1261371450101022723.text: The Heroes Act would boost SNAP benefits, providing $10 billion for the program, as well as an addition $150 million for The Emergency Food Assistance Program (TEFAP) to help local food banks meet the dramatically increased need.

1261371386578288640.text: It would also dedicate $4 billion to public housing agencies to respond to the coronavirus and protect the 2.2 million families in current housing and any families newly impacted by the pandemic, including those fleeing domestic violence.

1261370829432066048.text: It would extend the eviction and foreclosure moratorium that was created in the CARES Act, including all renters and homeowners.

1261370697932247041.text: It would also create a $75 billion Homeowner Assistance Fund to help cover mortgage payments, property taxes, insurance, utilities, and other costs.

1261370566268932101.text: The Heroes Act would create a $100 billion Emergency Rental Assistance Program that will help renters cover the costs of their utility bills and rent.

1261370468876972032.text: The House is in the process of debating the Heroes Act so next I'll go over housing, nutritional, and child provisions: https://t.co/ajMGXeFBlD

1261334888264892421.text: I am also pleased that these stimulus payments would be extended to Individual Taxpayer ID Number (ITIN) holders – a massive oversight in previous stimulus packages that left out so many who contribute so much to our economy and society.

1261334838398894082.text: While I still believe that we need recurring payments to ensure the financial security of families across the country I am pleased that families making less than $150,000 and individuals making less than $75,000 per year will get some assistance.

1261334587780857858.text: This is more than the stimulus payments in the CARES Act which was $1,200 per adult and $500 per child. Each eligible family will be able to receive up to $6,000.

1261334464308948994.text: This bill does not include recurring payments to individuals which I have been pushing for and will continue to push for. However, it does include another round of stimulus payments of $1,200 per family member.

1261334122737344517.text: $2 billion is set aside for worker training, and almost $1 billion is dedicated to helping process unemployment claims, funding that is much needed as states deal with record levels of claims.

1261334006462926848.text: It would also extend the $600 a week, supplemental federal unemployment payments through January 31, 2020 – providing some financial relief during this time of uncertainty.

1261333871901188098.text: The Heroes Act includes strong workplace standards and would require OSHA to issue strong, enforceable standards for infection control and prohibits employers from retaliating against workers who report infection control issues.

1261333658876678144.text: Next up, provisions that cover workers, the unemployed, and individuals:

1261310867741773824.text: The Heroes Act would provide an additional $100 billion for supporting hospitals and frontline care providers and strengthen Medicaid programs across the country.

1261310749667987458.text: New Jerseyans know just how devastating this virus is. We have lost so many of our friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues. Those who have gotten sick shouldn't have to worry about the $ of treatment which is why the Heroes Act ensures that every ppl can access free treatment.

1261310454493843463.text: We need a national strategy on testing with a clear timeline. The Heroes Act requires the Administration to submit such a plan to Congress by June 15th so that we can move forward as a nation in our fight against COVID-19.

1261310155272093696.text: It would also allocate an additional $75 billion for testing, contact tracing, and isolation measures. We won’t know the true scale of the health crisis until we have universal testing and to achieve that states and localities will need federal assistance.

1261308889229922304.text: The Heroes Act would establish a $200 billion Heroes’ Fund to provide hazard pay to the essential workers who are risking their lives each day during the pandemic.

1240717874915917824.text: It would suspend all consumer and small business credit payments on things like mortgages, student loans, small business loans, etc. throughout the crisis so that people won't fall deeper in debt while they are home or out of work because of the outbreak.

1240717052094091264.text: This plan proposes that "the Federal Reserve would be directed through a money-financed fiscal program, to fund automatic stabilizers in the form of at least $2,000 for every adult and an additional $1000 for every child for each month of the crisis."

1215748146560733185.text: Legislating is often a long and frustrating process but my Democratic colleagues and I will continue working on behalf of the American people. It is no accident that this year's NDAA is progressive, and I'll keep working in Congress to advance our priorities through legislation.

1215747466806595585.text: The resolution is called H.Con.Res.83, and it directs the President to terminate the use of America’s Armed Forces engaged in hostilities in or against Iran. Just as I supported the NDAA provision, I voted for this important resolution.

1215746809269714946.text: For example, although the House-passed NDAA included a provision I voted for prohibiting unauthorized war with Iran, the final version of the bill did not. But yesterday, the House voted on a similar War Powers resolution regarding the issue.

1215745831313252352.text: Legislating is a process of negotiation and compromise, so not every position we want will be included in a final bill. But our system is designed to allow legislative efforts to evolve – just because a policy isn’t in one bill doesn’t mean its doomed.

1215740568103460865.text: Legislating is a process of negotiation and compromise, so not every position we want will be included in a final bill. But our system is designed to allow legislative efforts to evolve – just because a policy isn’t in one bill doesn’t mean its doomed.

1215739780945915906.text: And this NDAA authorizes millions of dollars for military climate readiness and resiliency projects, directs DOD to plan for current climate-change vulnerabilities on our mil bases, and authorizes funding for military clean-energy research projects.

1215739195202981889.text: The bill also bans the use of PFAS forever-chemicals in firefighting agents used on military bases and in the packaging used for servicemembers’ field meals, known as MREs. This is an important step forward in limiting the exposure of PFAS chems in our food and water supplies.

1215737829113966592.text: And it repeals the “Widow’s Tax,” which is what happens when a fallen servicemember’s surviving spouse – who is entitled to two gov. annuity payments – has one payment reduced dollar-for-dollar by the other. Surviving spouses depend on these payments. I’m proud to vote to fix it.

1215737727100116997.text: For example – and for the first time ever – this year’s NDAA implements 12 weeks of paid parental leave for all federal employees. This leave policy includes leave for birth, adoption, or fostering.

1215736961937432579.text: But this year’s NDAA is among the most progressive ever enacted thanks to House Democrats prioritizing medical, family leave, environmental, and health provisions.

1215734328509988866.text: The NDAA is a massive bill (this year’s was over 1,000 pages long) that includes authorization and funding-level agreements for nearly every program run by the Department of Defense (DOD) – this includes servicemember pay, funding for arms upgrades, and so on.

1215733616535314433.text: Each year, Congress gets together to debate which national defense programs to reauthorize and which ones to reel in. This is done through a legislative vehicle known as the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA).

1215713990833328128.text: This bill is an important step towards preventing contamination of our food and water sources by a possibly-harmful chemical. It passed the House by a vote of 247 to 159 and now goes to the Senate.

1215713990174760960.text: Today, I voted for H.R. 535, the PFAS Action Act, to have the Environmental Protection Agency list PFAS chemicals as hazardous substances in order to strengthen scientific scrutiny of their possible impacts on our health.

1208119910829875201.text: While this list is long, the bills we passed included funding for hundreds of programs and provisions that will benefit communities across the country.  For more information visit the House Appropriations Committee website for a summary https://t.co/iEqoMZLnqN

1208118826400985088.text: The package also provides $4 billion for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), almost $400 million more than the President’s requested budget. This funding is crucial to ensuring that Medicare and Medicaid programs are responsive and effective.

1208118249956790272.text: $944 million is also included to improve maternal and child health and reduce maternal mortality and $286 million in funding set aside for the Title X Family Planning program.

1208117402220875776.text: This funding will go to crucial mental health resources for children and youth, substance abuse treatment and prevention, as well as increased funding for suicide lifeline and prevention efforts.

1208116790074712070.text: The inclusion of $10 million for a suicide prevention program is a step in the right direction for this nation to address mental health issues, which also benefits from the $5.9 billion for the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA).

1208115775011278861.text: Within the $8 billion significant increases for major public health efforts are included such as $10 million for the establishment of a suicide prevention program, $230 million to address tobacco & e-cigarettes, and $173.4 million for global disease detection efforts.

1208114664049127426.text: Specifically, the package includes $2.8 billion for Alzheimer’s research, $3.1 billion for HIV/AIDS research, $195 million for the Cancer Moonshot initiative, and $200 million for research to develop a universal flu vaccine, just to name a few.

1208113790455361536.text: We increased funding for the National Institutes of Health by $2.6 billion from last year so that we can pursue innovative treatments and cures to help Americans suffering from a variety of health issues.

1208112953960157187.text: In this minibus a substantial amount of funding was granted to many health programs that I care deeply about. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) was provided a total of $94.9 billion in funding, $4.4 billion more than in 2019.

1208110651417268224.text: And the bill prohibits DOT from playing political games with the funding. Congress is ordering that DOT use these funds to help infrastructure projects that are ready to go and serve an important regional and national need. This includes the Gateway Project.

1208110406457274370.text: It includes provisions that DOT must consider transportation infrastructure projects fairly, as quickly as possible, and must provide project applicants with enough advance notice to give everyone time to prepare their project application.

1208109186967580672.text: The bill funds grants that finance State of Good Repair projects at $200m, rail infrastructure and safety grants at $325m, and grants to Amtrak's Northeast Corridor at $700m. It also provides nearly $2b for grants that finance new transportation infrastructure.

1208108215831007234.text: The $86.2b for the Department of Transportation (DOT), and the provisions included in the bill, are important steps forward for the Gateway Project and replacing the aging tunnels that connect our district to New York.

1208107576707211265.text: While we need more than what is included in these bills, the money provided is a good baseline for us to build upon.

1208107575780298753.text: As a member of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, I know how desperately we need funding to fix our deteriorating roads, bridges, tunnels, and rail lines.

1208107172414074881.text: This money will go toward the medical services that the VA provides former servicemembers, finances upgrades to the VA's health records systems, and provides $125m to address the veterans' disability claims backlog.

1208106412762636288.text: In addition to assisting veterans transition to civilian life, these bills finance our nation's veterans' care programs and military construction projects. It finances the building of new military family housing at $1.3b and provides $216.5b for the Dept of Veterans' Affairs (VA)

1208105701509337090.text: ...$55m for the Homeless Vets Reintegration Program, $29m for Transition Assistance, and $300k to establish Disabled Veteran Program.

1208105700557238272.text: Funding was also allocated to programs that assist our veterans who need help reintegrating after service with $311m for the Vets' Employment and Training Service...

1208103143453671424.text: One of the bills provides $1.68b for the agencies and offices responsible for managing our nation's public lands and protecting our natural heritage for future generations to enjoy.

1208102172728188938.text: Importantly, this bill also funds the Environmental Protection Agency at $9.06b. This money provides hundreds of millions of dollars for important conservation and climate change mitigation work around the country.

1208100931298103296.text: It also provides $502m for the National Wildlife Refuge System and $68m for State and Tribal Wildlife Grants and it funds the National Park Service at $3.38 billion, to preserve and manage the natural wonders that dot our nation.

1208100034971082752.text: $495m is set aside for the Land and Water Conservation Fund, which finances projects to protect natural areas and water resources around the country.

1208099169526792192.text: These funding bills included money for important environment and conservation programs, too. One of the bills increases funding for NOAA's Climate Research programs to $170m and its Nat'l Ocean Service to $599m. This money finances government climate change mitigation projects.

1208098911916826629.text: The package also funds the Department of Energy at $38.5b, with $2.79b going to the office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, and $425m for the Advanced Research Projects Agency - Energy (ARPA-E). These are the offices whose research yields breakthrough in clean energy.

1208097414877499392.text: ...with $242m for its Wage and Hour Division, $582m for OSHA, and $106m for the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs - the federal offices that make sure workers are treated well and paid fairly.

1208097414047051781.text: Ensuring companies meet mandated labor standards is another important priority which is why I voted in favor of providing $12.4 billion for the Department of Labor...

1208096245799108609.text: In these bills we made it clear that education must be a priority.  Important programs such as Title I, Special Education, Head Start, Preschool Development Grants, Financial Assistance programs, and more all saw their funding levels increase over previous levels.

1208096245132275713.text: Education is another area where our investments have long lasting impacts that can benefit, or hinder, our progress as a society.

1208095373337726978.text: In order to ensure that our democratic institutions are operating fairly and efficiently we must have a comprehensive and accurate census. The $7.56 billion for the Census Bureau included in the funding package will help us carry out the 2020 Census.

1208094530915983361.text: We also secured $425 million for election security grants to protect the integrity of our elections, a priority that Republicans didn’t fund when they were in control of the House.

1208093735994757120.text: Included in those funding bills was $25 million for gun violence research at the CDC and NIH, this is the first time money has been dedicated to this desperately needed research in more than 20 years.

1208092656733216768.text: Earlier this week, the House passed 2 funding packages that averted another painful holiday shutdown. While the packages were not perfect, they funded vital programs that will help Americans across the country and include landmark funding for essential initiatives.

1204123256837591046.text: I will continue my work to support legislative efforts to make the United States a global climate leader.

1204123256015511552.text: We have the resources and the capacity to be global leaders on this issue and we have a responsibility to future generations to be good stewards of the world they will inherit.

1204123255231127552.text: Addressing global climate change will be difficult, but it is a challenge that our country must not hesitate to tackle.

1204121654311432192.text: A letter requesting robust funding for the Environmental Protection Agency’s Science and Technology Global Change Research program; and a letter requesting $154 million for the DOE’s Fuel Cell Technologies Office and $50 million for DOE’s Solid Oxide Fuel Cell programs.

1204121653535526912.text: Additionally, I signed on to appropriations requests aimed at conservation efforts around the country. I joined a letter requesting $3.576 million for the National Park Service’s Partnership Wild and Scenic Rivers program.

1204115229086535681.text: This legislation helps coastal communities prepare for extreme weather by directing the National Science Foundation and the National Institute for Standards and Technology to fund research into infrastructure improvements that account for extreme weather.

1204115228373458944.text: Furthermore, I am a cosponsor of H.R. 1317, the Coastal Communities Adaptation Act, introduced by Rep. Harley Rouda (D-CA).

1204114614625144832.text: I also signed on to a letter requesting $1.46 billion in funding for the Environmental Protection Agency’s Hazardous Substance Superfund Account.

1204114613543022592.text: I led a letter to the House Appropriations Committee requesting an increase in funds for the Department of Energy’s (DOE) Clean Cities Coalition program.

1204114612691636224.text: Congress has a responsibility to assist states and communities that want to protect themselves against climate change. That is why I supported efforts to finance climate change priorities in the yearly government appropriations process.

1204109866312314885.text: And H.R. 1429 provides $7.5 billion in federal grants for states and local governments that need assistance funding water infrastructure projects.

1204109865389568000.text: Both bills invest in our nation’s water infrastructure and its efficiency projects – H.R. 1162 provides $500 million for a federal competitive grant program that provides funding for projects that focus on water recycling technology.

1204109864521338880.text: Other bills I have cosponsored are H.R. 1162, the Water Recycling Investment and Improvement Act introduced by Rep. Grace Napolitano (D-CA) and H.R. 1429, the Drinking Water Infrastructure for Job Creation Act introduced by Rep. Maxine Waters (D-CA).

1204109048758583298.text: I am also a cosponsor of H.R. 4965, the LEARNS Act, introduced by Rep. Mark Pocan (D-WI), which expands the number of registered apprenticeships available for workers who can be paid living wages during their training, and who are given opportunities for upward job mobility.

1204108535065403399.text: This resolution asserts that our country needs to embrace clean energy jobs, modernize our aging energy grid, prioritize energy efficiency in our infrastructure projects.

1204108534184628225.text: I am a cosponsor of H.Con.Res.36, Supporting Efforts to Enact a Bold Jobs and Infrastructure Package that Benefits All Americans, Not Just Billionaires, introduced by Rep. Ted Lieu (D-CA).

1204108003215052801.text: This bill provides $7.5 billion in funding for investments in transportation infrastructure projects through the Better Utilizing Investments to Leverage Development (BUILD) grant program.

1204108002288164866.text: Our country needs to create green infrastructure and shift our energy sector’s workforce towards jobs that build and maintain that infrastructure. That is why I am a cosponsor of legislation like H.R 1428, the Transportation Infrastructure for Job Creation Act.

1204103078607237122.text: H.R. 9 passed the House of Representatives on May 2, 2019 by a vote of 231 to 190 and is currently awaiting review in the Senate.

1204103077902639112.text: This commonsense bill requires the United States to remain in the Paris Climate Accords and requires government agencies to set and achieve greenhouse gas emissions reduction goals.

1204103077084745730.text: We must reengage in the Paris Climate Accords, as the most powerful economy in the world, the United States has a responsibility to be a part of this international effort. That is why I voted in favor of H.R. 9, the Climate Action Now Act.

1204098728161955841.text: Mitigating the impacts of climate change must be a worldwide priority. I take this priority seriously and have supported legislative efforts to place our country at the forefront of the fight against climate change.

1204098727511756802.text: Throughout the day, I will be sharing some of my efforts in Congress to combat climate change.

1204098726635147265.text: Climate change is a real and urgent issue whose impacts are being felt around our country and around the world. Unusually dry summers, rising ocean temperatures, and melting ice caps are all threatening communities.

1201966891956350976.text: I call on my colleagues to come together and swiftly take up these crucial measures. Congress can act now, with the support of the country, to end the national nightmare of gun violence.

1201966890928750595.text: 60% of Americans support an assault weapons ban. I am a cosponsor of H.R. 1296, the Assault Weapons Ban of 2019, which would criminalize the sale or possession of any semiautomatic assault weapon or large capacity ammunition feeding device.

1201966890001805312.text: I am a cosponsor of H.R. 1236, the Extreme Risk Protection Order Act of 2019, which would incentivize and meaningfully fund efforts to install red flag protections nationwide. This bill respects local jurisdictions and encourages best practices.

1201966889125208070.text: 80% of Americans support a “red flag” law, which allows state courts to temporarily confiscate firearms from a person deemed a danger to themselves and others by family or law enforcement.

1201966888185745408.text: Any handgun owner would have to be at least 21 years old, undergo safety training, pass a background check, and renew their license every five years.

1201966887225188355.text: 82% of Americans support a licensing system for gun purchases. I am an original cosponsor of H.R. 687, the Handgun Licensing & Registration Act of 2019, which establishes a national licensing system.

1201966886201810944.text: H.R. 8 passed the House on February 27, 2019 by a vote of 240-190 and now awaits Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to bring it to the Senate floor for a vote.

1201966885174153218.text: 93% of Americans support universal background checks. I am a cosponsor of #HR8, the Bipartisan Background Checks Act of 2019, which would require a background check for every sale, possession, or transfer of a firearm in the U.S.

1201966884310179840.text: A recent Quinnipiac University poll found overwhelming, bipartisan support nationwide for commonsense gun reform. The good news is legislation exists right now in Washington to transform these popular ideas into law.

1197577660358123520.text: You don’t have to quit smoking in one day, start with day one. Visit https://t.co/nSnzDIXmns for more resources

1152278266516049922.text: @NASA Space exploration and the technological innovation that enables it has transformed the way we live our lives on a daily basis. For more information on these developments and other NASA Spinoff technologies, visit: https://t.co/nUG0Wi82KF

1152277995048054785.text: @NASA Additionally, NASA developed a special coating designed to protect equipment and helmet visors in space that are now used for scratch-resistant lenses.

1152277255214776322.text: @NASA If you have ever worn invisible braces, the first version of these were created using a transparent ceramic that was initially developed by NASA.

1152276593982746624.text: @NASA Land mine removal is made possible by a NASA partnership that utilizes surplus rocket fuel to destroy land mines without detonation.

1152275658539769857.text: @NASA Have you ever slept on a memory foam mattress? Memory foam evolved from a 1970s NASA funded research project looking to improve the seats of pilots & eventually was installed on space shuttles.

1152274607392604160.text: @NASA Walking down the street, you can spot almost everyone using hands free devices. Wireless headsets were one of the communications technologies developed by NASA to give astronauts more freedom without the inconvenience of chords.

1152273802547597312.text: @NASA Dustbusters are a common product in many households. Besides quickly cleaning up messes, this technology developed from an earlier Black & Decker tech used by NASA during the Apollo & Gemini missions to collect lunar samples via portable drill.

1152273112437862405.text: @NASA Have you ever wondered how your cell phone camera got to be so small? The technology for many of our cell phone cameras was engineered by NASA, trying to create cameras small enough to fit on spacecraft.

1152272488316977154.text: Did you know that @NASA technology impacts our daily lives right here on Earth? For this #FridayFocus, I will feature some facts of the space-related tech we use every day that highlights the need for continued investment in scientific research & the value of space exploration.

1146441216218849280.text: I will continue to fight for New Jersey and programs that impact the 8th District as the Senate considers these bills and the appropriations process progresses.

1146441110723670017.text: The Small Business Administration (SBA) was funded at $280 million, including money for Women’s Business Centers, Microloan Technical Assistance, and Small Business Development Center.

1146440667348033538.text: $300 million was provided for Community Development Financial Institutions, which provides targeted resources and innovate programs to connect public and private investments in mission-driven financial institutions.

1146440043130740737.text: Included was $600 million for Election Security Grants to fortify the integrity of our federal elections, along with $16.2 million for the Election Assistance Commission to continue to innovate security procedures and technology.

1146439264646942720.text: Finally, the House passed H.R. 3351, a bill to provide funding for the Department of the Treasury, the Judiciary, the Executive Office of the President, and other independent agencies such as the Small Business Administration. H.R. 3351 passed by a vote of 224 to 196.

1146438790317248513.text: Additionally, this bill increased funding for historic programs that have continued to support vulnerable Americans facing adverse living situations, including $410 million for Housing Opportunities for People with AIDS and $40 million for the Section 4 Capacity Building program.

1146437289888948224.text: Critically, H.R. 3055 blocked the Trump Administration’s public housing rule change on families of mixed immigration status, which would have threatened the livelihood of 55,000 children who are citizens or legal residents.

1146436555155881986.text: This bill also included $2.9 billion for the Public Housing Capital Fund $4.8 billion & for the Public Housing Operating Fund to help public housing agencies in local communities preserve and modernize existing housing units, while beginning to develop and construct new units.

1146435546367045634.text: $1.75 billion for the HOME Investment Partnership Program, which keeps low-income families on the verge of homelessness in stable housing and helps them on the path to homeownership – $500 million above the 2019 enacted level.

1146435007797485568.text: $300 million for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative, which leverages both private and public funding for community coalitions to restore distressed housing in vulnerable communities – $150 million above the 2019 enacted level.

1146434453964763136.text: $3.6 billion for Community Development Block Grants (CDBG), which thousands of cities and towns rely on for the improvement of their neighborhoods – $300 million above the 2019 enacted level.

1146433943341883394.text: The House appropriations bill not only rejected this request and kept these programs, but increased funding for many of them compared to last year’s enacted levels.

1146433518962192384.text: President Trump’s budget cruelly requested the complete elimination of critical programs like Community Development Block Grants, Choice Neighborhoods Initiative, and HOME Investment Partnership Program.

1146432971852959744.text: The House also voted to fund $50.1 billion for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, $5.9 billion above the previous year’s budget and $13.4 billion above the President’s request.

1146432421480620034.text: In total, the Department of Transportation was funded at $86.6 billion – $3.7 billion more than what the President asked for – to do its work of administering our country’s transportation networks.

1146431964230168576.text: And, thanks to a letter I led in April, the bill's report includes language reiterating that BUILD grants should be fairly awarded to public transportation and commuter rail projects. Over two years, BUILD grants awards have drifted away from these projects.

1146431494103207936.text: This might sound trivial, but Gateway Project opponents have been delaying it by insisting that it is too "reliant" on federal funding. The policy in this bill makes the point clear - NJ plans to pay the gov't back for its loans, so it should count as our share, not the govt's.

1146431383532920834.text: The bill also includes important policy that removes roadblocks from the Gateway Project. Thanks to an effort I led, the bill includes language clarifying that certain federal loans count as part of the project-share, if the loans are paid back with non-federal money.

1146425120916942848.text: The bill also raises funding for the Capital Investment Grants' New Starts program, which helps finance commuter rail rehabilitation projects, to nearly $1.5 billion. New Jersey can take advantage of the increase to upgrade our commuter rail network.

1146424628681818112.text: DOT administers many grants programs which it awards on a competitive basis. This year's bill funds the BUILD grants program, which funds huge infrastructure projects like Gateway, at $1 billion. At that funding level, there's a better chance that Gateway gets the money it needs.

1146424127793848320.text: Thanks to the work done by myself and my colleagues, the Department of Transportation appropriations bill included funding for New Jersey's infrastructure priorities including public transportation rehabilitation and the Gateway Project.

1146423435423297536.text: Furthermore, these funds will continue the VA’s transition to an electronic health record system and reduce the disability claims backlog in which over 450,000 veterans are waiting for a decision.

1146422880370069504.text: These extra funds are investments in mental healthcare services, suicide prevention outreach, care for women veterans, opioid abuse prevention, and homelessness assistance program.

1146422414550679553.text: The bill provides a much-needed $20.3 billion increase for the Department of Veterans Affairs, to provide for improved and increased access to care for our veterans.

1146422062673797120.text: Reports of deteriorating housing conditions for our servicemembers & their families is unacceptable, which is why this spending package includes increased funding for military family housing to ensure that all 2,006,171 military families have access to safe & quality housing.

1146421477211852802.text: The Environmental Protection Agency received $9.5 billion - $677 million more than last year - to carry out its work on conservation, environmental restoration, and compliance and enforcement work.

1146420859004948480.text: The Department of the Interior was funded at $37.2 billion to carry out the work of the Environmental Protection Agency, the Land and Water Conservation Fund, and the National Park System.

1146420182098894849.text: To continue to ensure access to adequate food and nutrition for those in our community who may be struggling, the package provides $6 billion for WIC, $23.96 billion for child nutrition programs, and $71.1 billion for SNAP

1146419548930920449.text: This funding will foster continued scientific breakthroughs that make the U.S. a leader in scientific and technological innovation.

1146419423479308290.text: The National Science Foundation, the nation’s leading research agency in non-medical fields, is funded at a level more than half a billion higher than in FY 2019.

1146417902796640258.text: $815 million was also included as an increase for NASA that will enable the agency to continue its deep space exploration endeavors, conduct science missions, and inspire the next generation of America’s STEM workforce.

1146416441182302209.text: The Commerce, Justice, Science (CJS) portion of this funding package provides $8.45 billion for the Census Bureau to conduct an accurate, advanced census free from any prejudice or discrimination.

1146415896174518272.text: H.R. 3055 is a $383.3 billion package of five bills that fund the departments of Commerce, Justice, Agriculture, Interior, Veterans Affairs, Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development. It passed by a vote of 227 to 194.

1146415501616263168.text: Importantly, the bill prohibits the President from using Defense funds to build a border wall at our troops’ expense.

1146414932797399041.text: The DoD also conducts life-saving medical research into numerous ailments that affect millions. The bill adds $453 million for cancer research towards breast cancer, prostate cancer, kidney cancer, ovarian cancer, lung cancer, melanoma, pancreatic cancer, & others.

1146414176774107136.text: It also continues to invest in education for military dependents by including $40 million for Impact Aid and $10 million for those with disabilities

1146413341662949376.text: The appropriations package provides funding to support a 3.1% military pay raise for our servicemembers.

1146413177401479168.text: Last year's Energy and Water appropriations bill provided $34 million for the program. This year's bill funded the program at $42.3 million. New Jersey, which has its own Clean Cities Coalition, can take advantage of this increase in funding to support green infrastructure.

1146412664316469249.text: In April, I led a letter to the Energy and Water Subcommittee urging them to raise funding for the Clean Cities Program, which helps states leverage federal money into green transportation upgrades.

1146411815615827969.text: The Energy and Water appropriations bill included $46.4 billion for agencies and programs that spur energy innovation, combat global climate change, and improve our nation's water infrastructure.

1146411336336859136.text: The Department of Labor is receiving $13.3 billion in funding this year to carry out the work it does on behalf of our nation’s workforce. This includes funding for workforce training, safety oversight, and labor protection enforcement.

1146410865824030720.text: The bill continues to support increased access to higher education by providing $492 million more for Federal student aid programs such as the Pell Grant, Federal Work Study, & the Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant Program.

1146410064221265921.text: Overall, the funding package provides an increase of $8.1 billion above the President’s request for K-12 education, including Title I Grants, special education, Title II-A grants, Title IV-A grants, and English language acquisition.

1146409467988389888.text: The bill also enhances resources for women’s health by increasing funding for programs that address maternal and child health, as well as a $114 million increase for the Title X Family Planning program and the 4 million people who depend on it.

1146408364144058369.text: Early childhood programs received an overall increase of $4 billion, enabling programs such as Head Start, Preschool Development Grants, and Child Care and Development Block Grants to continue serving the most vulnerable children in our communities.

1146407274052825088.text: The bill also provides $129 million more for SAMHSA programs that address mental health for children, suicide prevention, substance use treatment, and substance abuse prevention.

1146406886180347904.text: I have always supported critical investments in medical research, & I am glad that the package includes a $2 billion increase for the NIH, which will fund life-saving medical research into causes, cures, & treatments of diseases that impact millions of Americans.

1146405982962147328.text: H.R. 2740, is a four-bill appropriations package that funds the departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Defense, State and Energy. The $982.8 billion package passed by a vote of 226 to 203.

1146405426189221888.text: While these bills now await further action in the Senate, I would like to highlight some of the funding priorities included in these bills.

1146405334443024384.text: These funding packages will provide critical investments #ForThePeople in federal programs that millions of Americans rely on as well as maintain strategic national security objectives.

1146404924470759426.text: As of last week, the House of Representatives has now passed ten of the twelve appropriations bills that will fund the federal government until September 2020.

1144661644947185674.text: I want to thank you for taking the time to read today’s #FridayFocus on an extremely important topic.  If you have any questions or want more information on immigration legislation or data, please don’t hesitate to reach out to my office.

1144661157992706049.text: Debate on immigration policy frequently becomes heated but I ask that you keep the information I shared today in mind.  Our country has provided countless immigrants with an opportunity for a better life and our communities have benefited as a result.

1144661026622906368.text: H.R. 6 passed in the House of Representatives earlier this month and has not yet been scheduled for a vote in the Senate.

1144660552842657792.text: H.R. 6 doesn’t allow any of these people to “cut the line” and receive their citizenship on some sort of fast track, the process would take years. It simply rectifies a horrible mistake within our broken immigration system that left so many people in an uncertain state.

1144660082489221121.text: Jersey City is the home of 3,800 H.R. 6 protected immigrants, on avg the Dreamers arrived when they were 9 years old & the avg TPS recipient has been in here since 1995. These immigrants pay $48.6 million in Federal taxes and $23.7 million in State & local taxes each year.

1144659713587646464.text: Newark is home to 4,900 H.R. 6 protected immigrants.  On average the Dreamers arrived when they were 9 and most TPS recipients came to Newark in 2000. They pay $22.2 million in Federal taxes and $15.2 million in State and local taxes every year.

1144659083749933056.text: Elizabeth is home to 5,400 H.R. 6 protected immigrants, on average the Dreamers arrived at the age of 9 and TPS recipients came in 1997. These 5,400 people pay $35.4 million in Federal taxes and $21.3 million in State and local taxes every year.

1144658614638075905.text: Out of all the members on the House Budget Committee, I represent the district with the most individuals (19,500) covered by these programs and we would be severely impacted if the protections were removed.

1144658136982347776.text: This is why I am proud to be an original cosponsor of H.R. 6, the American Dream and Promise Act of 2019. This legislation would help to create a pathway to legal permanent resident status for Dreamers and TPS recipients.

1144657779195613184.text: We can argue about what immigration reform should look like, but we can’t deny that there are good people who would get “in line” if there was a line for them at all and that our immigration system has failed them.

1144657223823613953.text: Both groups contribute to our economy, work hard to improve their communities, and are Americans in their hearts.

1144656804816871424.text: Within our flourishing immigrant population, there is a subset that faces even more obstacles, Dreamers & TPS recipients.  Dreamers were brought to this country as kids & only know America as home while some TPS recipients have been here for decades after fleeing violence & chaos

1144656361684443136.text: These tax dollars fund infrastructure improvements, better school systems, Social Security, and countless other initiatives.

1144655949766057984.text: Beyond creating jobs, immigrants in the 8th District pay over $3.3 billion in taxes every year. This money goes to fund programs that positively impact our communities, and millions of Americans across the country.

1144655628062855168.text: If you walk down the street, chances are you’ll pass at least one business that was created by an immigrant or pass a neighbor who works at one.  The 8th District is home to nearly 12,000 of immigrant entrepreneurs.

1144655449435885569.text: Despite being less than 14% of the total population, immigrants make up about 30% of all new entrepreneurs.  We see the hard work of these entrepreneurs every day in the 8th District.

1144655273325449220.text: Stabilizing populations allow communities to attract businesses, create jobs, employ individuals and boost local government revenues - allowing everyone to benefit from increased investment.

1144655080857264128.text: In fact, the working-age population is only expected to grow by .3 percent each year for the next decade but immigrants will make up 85% of that growth.  This growth also prevents population decline in rural areas, which helps stabilize local populations.

1144654360615575552.text: This leads to lower productivity, an erosion of business dynamism, and a general decrease to our economic growth. Immigrants help make up for this shortfall of workers when they join the workforce.

1144653817335693313.text: Beyond the links between immigration and lower crime rates, immigration helps make our nation more productive.  Our workforce is aging and as baby boomers retire and birth rates fall, our working-age population shrinks.

1144653088915120128.text: According to one study by the @NewAmericanEcon , 9 out of the 10 American cities that received the largest influx of refugees between 2006 and 2015 saw violent crime rates drop over this same period. https://t.co/mYZHnp1B7u

1144651034347868161.text: As I said on Wednesday, I just don’t buy the claim that immigrants are criminals and the facts back me up.  On average, cities with substantial immigrant populations have lower crime rates than those with small immigrant populations.

1144650250021482496.text: The President chooses to characterize immigrants as criminals – a threat to our society, but as an immigrant myself, I know this is not the case. Immigrants are hard-working and patriotic contributors to our economy.

1144650010312814593.text: They are your neighbors, classmates, colleagues, and family members. Unfortunately, the Trump administration wants to stop immigrants from coming into the country.

1144649325311594503.text: The 8th District of New Jersey is a perfect example of how immigrants enrich our culture and contribute to our economy every day. Our district is home to over 330,000 immigrants who make up nearly 44% of our population.

1144648873471807491.text: The United States has always been a country that welcomes immigrants and gives them the opportunity to make a difference for their families, communities, and the country they have chosen to call home.

1144648517669085184.text: Today my #FridayFocus will take an in depth look at some of the positive contributions that immigrants make to both our society and our economy.

1142154133346144256.text: Thank you for joining me for this week’s #FridayFocus discussing the realities of poverty in America. Congress must continue to help those in need.

1142153025773023232.text: Living in, or at the edges of, poverty is a reality for many Americans and I am dedicated to fighting for programs that help those in need. No one in the 8th District or across the country should have to worry about food and shelter.

1142151808141484032.text: The Child Care and Development Block Grant helps fund services and programs that prepare children for success in school. In New Jersey there are almost 30,000 families enrolled in the program.

1142150989119709184.text: CHIP, the Children’s Health Insurance Program, along with Medicaid, provides health coverage to millions of children across the country, and SSI, Supplemental Security Income, helps provide funds to seniors who are unable to work.

1142150295931314178.text: The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) offers nutrition assistance to about 43 million families each year, and kept 8.4 million people out of poverty, in 2015 alone. In New Jersey that year there were over 900,000 people receiving benefits.

1142149368448978944.text: During the ongoing appropriations process I signed letters requesting funding for these programs, among others. Because I know the real impact they can make on people’s everyday lives.

1142149319572828161.text: I have been, and remain, a vigilant supporter of programs such as SNAP, CHIP, SSI, and the Child Care & Development Block Grant.

1142148456129208320.text: Furthermore, the Administration also wants to impose harsher work requirements for people who seek benefits. This would lower the amount of people eligible for benefits and is a cruel form of discrimination against those who are disabled and unable to work.

1142147743353380864.text: The White House also wants to implement an $8.6 billion spending cut to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. This would decrease available funds for grants and programs that help people afford housing.

1142146822632349698.text: If the Administration does change the measurement data, 300,000 children and 150,000 seniors would lose their health coverage from Medicaid. This is without the President’s proposed $1.5 trillion cut from Medicaid, which would cause even more people to lose their health coverage.

1142146012397625344.text: The current measurement of poverty in the U.S. uses the Consumer Price Index but this Administration wants to switch to an alternative measure of inflation that would decrease the amount of people eligible for certain programs such as Medicaid and SNAP.

1142145349731139588.text: In 2017, the 8th District had a poverty rate of 15.5%, and 22.5% of children were living in poverty. However, the Trump Administration wants to build more barriers and make it more difficult for families and individuals to sign up for and receive benefits.

1142144377378267138.text: Therefore, there are millions more Americans who are struggling to make ends meet but are not categorized as under the poverty line, meaning they cannot receive benefits from the federal government, which in turn, punishes them financially.

1142143646504030208.text: This number does not consider the current reality for a family that may be enduring hardships but doesn’t fall below the official poverty line. The National Center for Children in Poverty estimates a family requires an income of twice the poverty level to support their needs.

1142143512957394944.text: Unfortunately, almost 40 million Americans, about 12% of the population, fall below the poverty line. Even more frustrating is the realization that nearly 1 in 5 children under the age of 18 live in poverty.

1142142215092703232.text: In the 116th Congress, my colleagues and I have made it our highest priority to pass legislation that improves daily life for all Americans. Helping working families become financially secure and providing them with extra resources is one part of this mission.

1139605795430129664.text: Thank you for joining me for this #FridayFocus to discuss how the appropriations process works and the importance of the process to our democratic system.

1139605027075559430.text: The appropriations process is an important aspect of Congress’s Constitutional power of the purse. Funding levels determined during the appropriations process are crucial to the performance of agencies and implementation of public programs.

1139604139221159936.text: Upon both chambers adopting an identical spending bill, the bill is then sent to the President for his signature or veto.

1139602773677359105.text: Both chambers must pass an identical bill before it can be signed into law. If there are differences the chambers can then continue to pass amendments to each other until issues are resolved or can hold a conference of members in order to get an agreement.

1139601229779210240.text: Once the spending bill passes the House, it is sent to the Senate for consideration. The Senate can also make changes to the bill in the form of amendments. These amendments usually become the topic of debate between the two chambers.

1139600296412401664.text: When a minibus like this comes to the House Floor members are given the chance to offer amendments and change funding levels of the bill before it receives a vote.

1139599468712681472.text: The debate this week centered on a minibus, a package of 4 smaller appropriations bills. This minibus, H.R. 2740, considered spending limits for Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Defense, State and Foreign Operations, and Energy and Water Development.

1139598643948920832.text: Following passage in the Appropriations Committee the spending bills will be brought to the House floor for a vote. The spending packages can be voted on individually, all-together, or in smaller groupings known as a “minibus”.

1139597935073738752.text: Each subcommittee will then mark up their spending proposal before sending it to the full committee for consideration.

1139597168975781888.text: Next, each subcommittee will create a budget that allocates their total predetermined funding to the programs and agencies under their jurisdiction. This power of Congress to determine spending levels is vital for enforcing checks and balances.

1139596402315714562.text: Some of the letters I signed supported funding for medical research, affordable housing programs, community health centers, community development grants, law enforcement grants, and gun violence prevention measures.

1139595362841366528.text: Once these letters are circulated, members formally submit their funding priorities to the 12 subcommittees.

1139594808178216960.text: The appropriations process begins in the House, it is important the proposed funding levels reflect the needs of constituents, not just the White House’s desired budget.

1139594745938923521.text: Members lead & sign onto letters to the Appropriations Committee outlining requests important to their district.

1139593636860059648.text: The appropriations process began a few months ago. After reviewing the President’s proposed budget, Members of Congress have an opportunity to submit funding requests to support various programs, agencies, and priorities.

1139592854471397377.text: This week, the House of Representatives started debating amendments on our first appropriations package for FY 2020. For this week’s #FridayFocus let’s take a deeper look into how the appropriations process works.

1137055646073925632.text: As a cosponsor, I am outraged that any American could be denied a home because of hate.

1137055584337969153.text: H.R. 2402, the Fair and Equal Housing Act, is a standalone provision of the Equality Act that would ensure no person is turned away from housing because of bigotry against sexual orientation and gender identity.

1137054749205958656.text: It is time now for the Senate to take up H.R. 5 and enact these landmark federal protections into law.

1137053895098863616.text: H.R. 5 is a comprehensive federal package that would forbid discrimination in housing, services, and employment on the basis of sexual and gender identity. As an original cosponsor, I proudly voted for its passage.

1137053118699573249.text: Last month’s historic House passage of H.R. 5, the Equality Act, demonstrates the political support for legislation enshrining equal protection under the law for LGBTQ+ Americans.

1136025443394605057.text: As the representative for the 8th district, the home of many hard-working immigrant families, I am proud that the House is voting on this legislation and call on Senator McConnell to stop blocking legislation from the Senate floor.

1136025383533514752.text: H.R. 6 would also help to create a path to LPR status for those who were eligible for TPS and DED on January 1, 2017 and have been here for three years, but were unable to take advantage of the programs due to President Trump’s policies.

1136025287966232577.text: Dreamers who came to the U.S. before the age of 18 and have been here for more than 4 years while completing educational benchmarks will be able to apply for ‘conditional’ LPR status, while full LPR status will be granted as dreamers continue with their professional careers.

1136025204851916801.text: That is why I am proud to be a cosponsor of H.R. 6, the American Dream and Promise Act. This legislation establishes a process for eligible Dreamers to apply for lawful permanent resident (LPR) status, eventually allowing them to obtain citizenship.

1136025073448640512.text: Since taking over the House, our democratic majority has consistently considered and debated legislation that seeks to restore the gaping holes left by this administration’s actions.

1136024975918477313.text: Dreamers, TPS, and DED holders have been left floundering by the Trump Administration and are a casualty of this President’s xenophobic fear-mongering.

1136024897564618752.text: President Trump has also ended the Temporary Protected Status (TPS) and the Deferred Enforced Departure Program (DED) for many people who fled their homes years ago due to turmoil and have since made America home.

1136024828585172993.text: DACA allowed our neighbors, classmates, colleagues, and friends to come out of the shadows and continue contributing to our economy and society.

1136024661471485953.text: These Dreamers came to America as small children, through no fault of their own. Some did not even know they weren’t citizens until they were old enough to get their drivers license.

1136024573747634176.text: Two years ago, President Trump terminated the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, sending millions of young people, who call America home, into a future of fear and uncertainty.

1134527035936825345.text: Our electoral system is the foundation of American democracy. A government for the people and by the people stands on the success of free and fair elections. I remain committed to supporting measures that would prevent foreign interference and make our system more transparent.

1134522130362699782.text: H.R. 1 passed the House on March 8, 2019. I call on my Senate colleagues to quickly take up H.R. 1 and enact the critical change Americans are demanding.

1134520177075335168.text: Additionally, all states would be required to use only U.S.-manufactured voting systems by the general federal election of 2022.

1134519308418199554.text: H.R. 1 would also establish the Election Security Bug Bounty Program to incentive rapid, real-time support from independent technical experts – catching vulnerabilities and stopping hostile actors.

1134518336061153287.text: Ballot security is a chief priority following the attacks by foreign governments on our 2016 election. H.R. 1 includes federal funding for the adoption of paper ballots and annual risk-limiting audits to increase best practices nationwide.

1134517497292632064.text: H.R. 1 was a wide-ranging package of legislation with provisions dictating new safety protocols, safeguards to end voter suppression, and restrictions on the influence of dark money.

1134516014438395904.text: H.R. 2997 and H.R. 2660 were also included in the bill language for H.R. 1, the For the People Act, which was a priority for the new Democratic majority in the House. I was proud to be an original cosponsor and vote for its passage.

1134515173933420545.text: Political organizations would be required to disclose any donor who has given $10,000 or more during an election cycle and a domestic corporations with significant foreign control would be banned from spending money on an American election.

1134514277354737667.text: H.R. 2997, the DISCLOSE Act, would establish new conditions for federal election spending practices to increase transparency.

1134513528839319553.text: H.R. 2660, the Election Security Act, would require states to use paper ballots, implement nationwide cybersecurity standards, and fund grants for local jurisdictions to improve voting system security.

1134512858325274624.text: H.R. 4, the Voting Rights Advancement Act, would reinstate Section 4(b) of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and require states with a history of voter discrimination to first clear any change in election practices with the Department of Justice.

1134505101798891520.text: The integrity of our democratic elections is under attack from all sides – foreign interference, efforts to suppress voting rights, and corrupt campaign finance. Recently, I’ve cosponsored the following legislation:

1134503671276953600.text: Meeting with you and hearing your priorities for our community contributes to the bills I support. I’ve heard from many of my constituents about concerns with the current state of American elections.

1134135010305486849.text: H.R. 1236, the Extreme Risk Protection Order Act, would allow families or law enforcement to ask for a gun violence prevention order from a court. The order would temporarily prohibit an individual who poses a threat to themselves or others from obtaining a firearm.

1134133528243908609.text: Ethan’s Law, would make it a crime for a firearm to be left unsecured if there’s a reasonable expectation that a child could gain access to it. This law seeks to prevent the horrific accidental shootings that can happen when a child gets hold of an unsecured gun.

1134132201149337602.text: H.R. 2585, the Resources for Victims of Gun Violence Act, would create a program to help the victims of gun violence with a wide range of personal needs that are often left unaddressed in the aftermath of gun violence.

1129479217023000576.text: New Jerseyans rely on the ACA to provide comprehensive, quality, and affordable care which is why I remain committed to working with my colleagues to work in the interest of our communities and their health.

1129478330716250112.text: This bill would rescind the Administration’s junk insurance plan rule and restore critical funding for the consumer education and outreach.

1129476922143117313.text: The Administration has taken deliberate action to restrict individual enrollment by promoting junk insurance plans that can discriminate against individuals with pre-existing conditions, reducing the enrollment period, & slashing funding for consumer outreach & enrollment by 90%.

1129475111030087684.text: Additionally, this bill takes important steps towards strengthening the ACA by investing in consumer outreach and educational activities, as well as enabling more states to establish their own state-based marketplaces.

1129474103830831107.text: This bill would offer fixes to loopholes such as this that often delay or preclude generic drugs from coming to market in a timely manner.

1129473052146905091.text: This will pause the clock on the exclusivity and prevent other generic companies from bringing a similar drug to market.

1129472995280474112.text: The first generic applicant to the FDA is granted 180 days of market exclusivity. Sometimes applicants will delay seeking final approval though they have begun the application process.

1129471525160181761.text: This bill begins to address this issue by promoting increased competition and bringing generics to market faster to provide more affordable options.

1129471425826435072.text: Research suggests that as many as 24% of Americans opted out of filling a prescription in the past year due to the prohibitive costs.

1129471276689559553.text: H.R. 987 includes three bills to lower prescription drug costs by enabling generic drugs to get to market quicker, and four measures to protect the quality of coverage options and expand enrollment.

1129468064393846784.text: On Thursday, the House passed H.R. 987, the Strengthening Health Care & Lowering Prescription Drug Costs Act, a package of multiple proposals that will lower prescription drug costs, strengthen the ACA & expand on previous legislation Democrats have passed.

1129467068909281281.text: Building on last week’s #FridayFocus, I wanted to talk about legislation that Democrats have introduced, and passed, in the House of Representatives that continues our fight to provide affordable, quality care for American communities.
